bibl.title: Letter from Arthur C. Jacobson to Philip Showalter Hench, November 18, 1949

div1.p: Jacobson informs Hench that he does not believe Reed examined yellow fever cases in Brooklyn during his internship. There are no records of any yellow fever outbreaks during this time period.

div1.head: Letter from Arthur C. Jacobson to Philip Showalter Hench, November 18, 1949
div1.opener:
ARTHUR C. JACOBSON, M. D.
95 PIERREPONT STREET
BROOKLYN 2. N. Y.
November 18, 1949
Philip S. Hench, M. D.
102-110 Second Avenue Southwest
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
There is no yellow fever in the records of the diseases
treated in the three hospitals in which Reed interned, during his
periods of service.

When I spoke of frequent ravages of yellow fever in
Brooklyn I did not mean to imply that Reed might have seen something
of the disease. The last epidemic to visit Brooklyn was in 1860.
There was a long record before that -- 1702, 1804, 1805, 1809, 1822,
1823, 1856, 1857.

It is my opinion that the story about General Kean is
true -- that he was Reed's first case.

Another six copies will be sent to you and reprints when we
receive them. I shall be grateful if you will send them to interested
friends, relatives, etc.

It has been a great pleasure to have had these exchanges
with you in the study of Reed data.

Medicine has glamorous aspects. This, surely, is one
of them.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, Arthur C. Jacobson ACJ/h
